Comment: So let me get this straight… the national emergency tariffs on auto and steel and aluminum dropped to zero… how is it a national emergency then?   Also hurts car manufacturers in America who are paying 25% tariffs on USMCA parts while UK tariffs max out at 10%
Author: chunkyfunky

Comment: By all accounts this the timing of this was a surprise to the British side (I can't imagine Starmer deliberately scheduling a call in the second half of a crucial Arsenal match), so maybe Trump is desperate for something to pull out of the bag. There's certainly a *lot* of areas still outstanding, pharmaceuticals for one.    We still have the state visit in the diary, so maybe our strategy here is to say "We, the UK, will provide a theatrical stage and enough diplomatic special effects to make your incoherent trade policy screenplay look like a tentpole blockbuster. Just keep dripping in the concessions and we'll start work on the sequel".

Comment: So, Brits are going to import US beef because we have plenty? Then why is hamburg $5/pound and steaks $20/lb?   And if I recall, Britain banned our beef because most US beef goes to slaughter before age 2, and BSE does not typically manifest symptoms in beef until after that age.   There is a reason most developed countries don't want to import food grown in  the US=plenty of chemicals (pesticides, etc) are banned in other countries for use in food products, so it is not really fair to expect your country to follow rules and then import product from a country where they don't have to follow those rules.
